Well, as a start I'd like to say that I didn't want to play this game for a fairly long time, I bought a deluxe edition in June 2013 (It had belt buckle, OST disc and Nukecity DLC). I installed it only around November of the following year and got to actually play it somewhat in beginning of May. And, yes, I underestimated it. The game itself looks better than its ancestors in fact, it is clearly seen at points, faces show expressions and the characters don't look like robots...The graphics did become better as well, comparing to MW3, it's made a decent leap. Everything, looks better, somewhat like Mirror's Edge especially to the end of the game when things start exploding (YEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEAH). The story is divided into three parts. Let me tell about every of them in short:  First story: As usual, flashbacks of Woods, who did survive in Laos (or it was Vietnam?..) Anyway, this looks pretty interesting, has some stupid moments, some ridiculous twists, but to be honest, I liked this part the most. It ends at somewhat middle of entire game  Second story: The main part, protagonist of which is son of Alex Mason, who follows old foe of his father and so on and so forth. This part takes place in 2025. it has some futuristic features, but all in all, the gameplay is pretty sample to first. I didn't like this one too much, even though it has a pretty charismatic character named Harper, and that it has the most conscious plot...The thing is that this part looks a lot like Crysis because of those future weapons and stuff. I know, that it hardly would look any different, if you want to make some close-future shooter, but still.   Third story: Is kinda the ♥♥♥♥♥iest for me. You command a squad that goes all around the world, defending different places from the main villain's troops. It's made as a tactical part of game, you have around 10 soldiers and machines under your control and you can control every of them on your own, but as tactics it's pretty useless...Choose all your troops and command to attack enemy, not a big deal. I finished it as well, so there.  The thing I did like about the game is the variety of endings. The thing is that the only two things you're going to care for are Woods and Harper, so that doesn't matter way much, but in game it is pretty exciting, to choose things, knowing it may affect the game  Sound is good, I really liked the ending, even though not fan of A7X, but yeah, pretty cool  I hardly played multiplayer, but it looks pretty fun too, a lot like MW2 which I did like  In the end, would I recommend this game? Yes, if you're afraid to waste your time on one more 'CoD ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shooter omg', then leave your fears, it's pretty decent even though pretty easy (played on hard difficulty, died only 7 times throughout the game, the squad was lost only once)  In the end, I'd say 8.4/10. Would have been better if not that stupid tactical feature Thanks for reading, play games!

I'm not a big fan of this  Call of Duty  like I used to be. Looking at it as a game on its own however, it has some great values within the  Call of Duty  series, the biggest one in my eyes being the choices you're able to do in the campaign to change the story. It is perhaps the truly innovative factor of this game, considering the franchise is known for not thinking outside the box and being repetitive.  One of my favorite aspects of the campaign's story is that I feel that the franchise finally got a villain with a real purpose, that you can even empathize with, and not a random terrorist seeking senseless war. The story is genuinely interesting and very well written, the timeline being split between the 80s and the future, in 2025. The section which the player rides a horse is probably one of the coolest gameplay moments in  Call of Duty's  campaign history. The cutscenes are extremely engaging too, you can't help but pay attention to them.  Speaking of which, the gameplay at the very core remains the same. This serves to both its benefit and disadvantage, it's good to feel the  Call of Duty  'essence' present while playing, but the vicissitude some were definitely looking for is lacking. The A.I. remains stupid, standing in your way and taking bullets. The new strike force missions leave a lot to be desired, and while they affect the story, they're thankfully not mandatory.  The multiplayer is the same one you know from previous games, however it implemented some very nice features. The league play mode, the much better designed emblem system, wildcards, and new game modes such as hardpoint and multi-team death match being some of them. Things that kinda bummed down my personal experience though were the removal of wager matches, CoD points, and some reticle customization, I digress though.  The theater mode returns better than ever, and I believe  Treyarch  tried their best in making this the most balanced  Call of Duty.  Nonetheless the map design this time around is unfortunately disappointing, and the DLC remains expensive and not worth the price. It is particularly bothersome that the Peacekeeper is the only new weapon available out of all the packs. I also thought it was strange not to see some of the 80s weapons in the multiplayer.  Zombies was flabbergasting to me. TranZit is simply  awful,  grief is lame, and the new characters are downright annoying and utterly unfunny crap, especially Marlton. I couldn't find the appeal to the map design nor the story in the mode up until Origin, which   turned out to be false.   There are some gameplay design decisions that'll simply make you ask  why,  such as the fact that they've only included the very desired AK-47 in the map Mob of the Dead.  It feels incredibly worthless to make a world map to include just a very small amount of locations as well, when I saw that I was sure they would make a Rezurrection-kind of DLC which would emcompass classics such as Kino Der Toten and Ascension, but instead they wasted it in more poorly made multiplayer maps. Thankfully, the soundtrack of this one remains solid, for the most part. Including artists such as  Johnny Cash,   Avenged Sevenfold,  and  Malukah.  Sadly,  Elena Siegman  only returns in one song on Origin.  Kevin Sherwood  still wrote excellent songs for the mode though.  This is far from being the best  Call of Duty  in the series, but  Treyarch  did a solid job, especially with the campaign. It manages to be significantly refreshing and fun, despite its issues.  7.3/10.0

The way that Call of Duty has been going these days, I was not expecting much with this game. However, I was pleasantly surprised by this Call of Duty outing.  Call of Duty games of late have not been very variable. The campaigns have been basically mission after mission of shooting into huge crowds of enemies while trying not to be killed, and the multiplayer's just been the same over and over again, but with minor changes. With Black Ops 2, however, this has changed slightly, and for the better. The campaign does have its fair share of shooting and running and craziness, but there's also some stealth elements mixed in there, as well as some interesting new mechanics, for example the Millimeter Scanner which can detect cloaked enemies, and the real-time strategy-esque'Strike Force' missions. This, on top of a surprisingly good storyline, helps to breathe a little new life into the ageing Call of Duty series.  The multiplayer's had some changes as well - Whilst retaining the gameplay of previous games, new weapons and attachments make the game just a bit more interesting. In addition, the Create-a-Class menu has been completely reworked, now allowing players to select more than one attachment by default, as well as the new Wildcards, taking some of the Perks from previous games and reworking them.  All of this makes Call of Duty: Black Ops 2 one of the better Call of Duty games, up there with Modern Warfare. If you're going to play any Call of Duty game, this game is not a bad choice.

Alright, now that Apocalypse is out, I'll try and do my best to create an elaborate review of Black Ops II.  Let's start off with the campaign, I found it was kind of good in some ways, I mean it is really good, with a pretty decent story and the addition of you making the choices of getting a different ending, but I found that the characters didn't felt that good like it did in Black Ops 1, and as for a sequel story, I didn't like many of the old 20th century missions, there's probably too many of them in my taste, and in a mission with Mason, there's the 'numbers' again, but that was just bad..   You can ride a horse, do a wannabe RTS things here and there, get to fly a jet, make your decisions on different events of the campaign, I think they're actually stepping up their game.  Multiplayer: Ooh boy this is the hard part, with success always comes the haters... As for the gameplay I found it was very fluid and smooth and the maps are amazing, with these 'new' graphics. One reason I pick Black Ops and Black Ops 2 over the Modern Warfare Series (Excluding MW1) is the colors, this may sound weird, but indeed these games have clear colors, and bright ones too. This game is like my pick and play if I'm in a good mood, since everytime I play I feel like I achieve something with the level system, or trying to get gold weapons, which is a pretty good system to get you busy for a long time.  Zombies: Alright so I'm a fan of Zombies in Call of Duty, in this one I could clearly see they were going for something different: TranZit, which was the worst map in my opinion. When on the bus, power station or going from one place to the other in the fog, the game has a slight chance of Crashing, and also the fact that not many people play in PC, I should've put this in the Multiplayer bit too, trying to find a match in Zombies takes around 10 minutes but don't get too excited if you find at least ONE person to play with, since the maps worth playing are HUGE, and there are quitters all over the place. I would recommend getting a friend to play with. The stock game comes with 4 maps, Tranzit, Bus depot, town, and farm, each one being a place in Tranzit as a stand alone map. These maps are boring once you've played them a lot, but No one plays Tranzit, because everyone plays Town, so the stock game in Zombies is really bad.  As for the buildables, I loved the portable engine to power up stuff, the Zombie Shield I never saw anyone use it and it is on all maps, which is the worst thing they could've kept for all maps... As for Grief, No one plays it, I never played it, I didn't like it either, I rather play zombies in a coop way.  Revolution: I liked it, got it when it was coming out, 4 original multiplayer maps, a new Multiplayer weapon, the Peacekeeper which I used a lot, a very good zombies map, Die Rise, really felt like CoD Zombies.  ... Oh and a new gamemode, wow I even forgot that existed because no one plays it, so I never got to play it, although the idea sounded pretty good, as for you turning into the zombie.  Uprising: Amazing Maps, a remake of Firing Range, a classic from Black Ops 1, and Mob of the Dead, probably the best zombies map in BO2 by far. Sadly, no new weapon or anything fancy.  Vengeance: Probably the only reason that I have to get it is the Cove map, everything else doesn't look convincing, and Buried looks too easy. I didn't get it, but my call is to wait until it goes on sale.  Apocalypse: Maybe the only reason to get this is Origins, a really fun map, although hard, but to learn everything hidden in origins is quite the job, and I really like it. Only thing I didn't like is the combination of steampunk robots in a 1918 era with also the templars, just wasn't too good. As for multiplayer goes, 2 reused maps, not apealing, but I didn't have stadium from Black Ops 1, so that only makes 1 reused map, which isn't a big surprise Treyarch got lazy at the last DLC...

I love this game. I still can't believe how much I enjoyed the story mode in specific. I never thought I would want to replay a call of duty campaign but it's that good. The game play is standard call of duty with some new flavors added but the actual story itself was enthralling. The best word that comes to mind is haunting. I usuaully am not startled or shocked by graphic content but some of the scenes depending on how you play are chilling.   It's a shame that the game crashed as often as it did, pretty much every other mission it would crash and black out the screen of my computer and the only thing I could do is restart the entire machine. This got pretty old quick, especially when you're going for a no death run on veteran and it crashes 75% of the way through or even worse, at the end cut scene.   Even with the fault in the programming, I still love this game. With that being said, I wish they would of expounded more on the campaign's 'decisions' to let you fail. The game has moments that depending on your preformance will effect the outcome of the story usually affects certain dialogue sequences but I would of really liked it if some of the choices actually changed the entire outcome of the story all together, even bypassing or presenting alternative missions. I understand that they had a lot to work on, especially with the ramped up zombies mode and the ever popular multiplayer being a key focus. However, stuff like the avenged sevenfold cameo, while entertaining, was something that I couldn't help but think that the time spent on making that scene could of been used to make the game itself better.   The following is spoilers so if you have not played the game, be aware that the following will ruin the story for you. I love the villian of this game, by far he has been my favorite. He is well thought out and his motivations not only make sense but you genuinely feel for the guy. While I am very happy to see woods back, I thought that he was a little out of place. The only thing that didn't really make sense was why woods hated menendez so much. I understand that he's a bad guy and they are against him, but what did menendez do to him? I'm pretty sure kravchenko was the one that was responsible for torturing him but was handed over to menendez. I guess he blamed them both equally.   The story does a solid job at showing the price of conflict. Most games come off really pretentious when they're talking about the horrors of war but this game simply nails it. Easily the most haunting scene I have witnessed in modern gaming, when they finally show his sisters face at the end, I got chills. I got even more chills when he joins her. I love that about Treyarch, while they may not be the best programmers, they are incredible story tellers. Also I really enjoyed the fact that the game uses a lot of current real world tech to show off the possible future that we are looking at but also able to blend it with traditional game play of the previous black ops that helped finish that story.  I do wish they would of gotten Ed Harris to return as the voice for Hudson instead of replacing him with Michael Keaton. His portrayal ends up coming off as more ice cream than ice cube. I don't understand why they didn't just make a new character for this game, Hudson was a CIA handler and they could of just as easily assigned them a new one. That was really the only complaint I had with the story mode, the rest of the voice acting is really solid ESPECIALLY woods. James Burns is a fantastic voice actor and I would really like to see him come back in future installments to lend his talents.   Overall, this has been my favorite call of duty game in the series. I cannot recommend it highly enough, but to be honest, it might be better to get it on console. I had a nightmare of a time getting through some of the levels without the game crashing. If you can stomach the bugs for the story then I gaurantee you will not be disappointed, I only wish that I could of played the game when it was new and gotten to experience the online features in their prime.

The campaign is salvageable, it offers a few fun missions to play and even replay to see a different outcome like the endings (or get more achievements if you care about those) which was a really good addition to CoD. But, the campaign isn't as epic as Modern Warfare 1. The Strike Force missions were a cool new addition but poorly executed and very frustrating, the unit AI wasn't on the top, I almost lost them on most occasions. With Zombie mode, the same can be expected as previous Treyarch CoD that offered that mode although, I'd still say Left 4 Dead offers a more satisfying experience.   PROS: +Campaign is interesting and offer decent playtime. +Story choices are often tough and encourage replay. +Amazing soundtrack and theme by Trent Reznor, Nine Inch Nails' frontman. +Strike Force missions are an innovative play (even if I didn't like them).  CONS: -Unstable and very buggy at release (a year later, game is finally playable). -Extremely linear experience. -Lots of invisble walls, forcing you to head towards the developers chosen direction or do a specific action to trigger a pre-rendered lame animation. -Vague objectives at times. -Enemy A.I's. always focus their fire on you instead of easier friendly A.I. targets nearby. -Strike Force missions were beyond annoying on Veteran difficulty setting. Limited replay from the points system. Poor friendly A.I. makes it close to impossible to beat it which made me skip those missions entirely. -NO DEDICATED SERVERS FOR THE MULTIPLAYER... meaning, don't play this game online as it is pointless. Get Battlefield 3 instead for online play. -Zombies mode is stagnant (doesn't offer anything new but you can expect the same thing from previous Treyarch Zombie modes).  OVERALL: I played this game for like, 3 hours at the game's release and lost interest at the campaign's Strike Force missions. The SF missions really annoyed the hell out of me especially if you failed a SF mission, you had limited replay points to change the outcome. So now, a year later and after having played CoD Ghosts, I can honestly say that I preferred Ghosts than Black Ops 2... in fact, I'd say Black Ops 1 was better than its sequel. Ghosts was more forgiving and the hit detection system seemed more refined too.   RECOMMENDATION: I would say that BLOPS 2 would be an acceptable addition to the series but please, buy it at a reduced price! Ain't worth spending the big bucks for the campaign alone!  RATING: 6.5 / 10

Before reading this review, do not be fooled by my hours played, as they only represent my hours on the campaign. My real hours played is much higher, around 150+ on the multiplayer.  Call of Duty: Black Ops II is considerably better than a lot of the other CODs on Steam. If you want to play Zombies, prepare to pay £34.99 extra for the Season Pass, because the map that comes with the game (Green Run) is crap. The campaign is the only COD campaign so far with multiple endings. It is also one of the best campaigns. Multiplayer is very fun, with great customisable options for your class. If you want to play multiplayer and you own the Season Pass, you will need to disable the DLC in your library otherwise matchmaking will be narrowed down so you can only play with other Season Pass holders. And considering the fact that the peak multiplayer players for the last 30 days was about 5,500, you will struggle to find even a Team Deathmatch game with the DLC maps enabled.  The optimisation for the PC port of this game is quite good, and it runs a lot better than Advanced Warfare, Ghosts and Black Ops 3. The port has a variety of options, such as an FOV slider ranging from 65 (console default) to 90. However, the port is not flawless.  Ever since I have updated to Windows 10 (29th July 2015, its release date), I have experienced severe screen tear on Black Ops 2. I checked Black Ops 3 and the original Black Ops, and I get screen tear on both of those games too. I did not want to use V-sync, as that would cause mouse acceleration, severely affecting my aim, so I enabled 'Windowed (fullscreen)' as my display option for the game. This stopped the screen tear, however my frames per second were considerably lower. I turned on V-sync, which solved the FPS lag and locked my framerate to 60. For some reason, when I use V-sync with 'Windowed (fullscreen)', I do not get mouse acceleration, even when using V-sync. This fixed my problem, however this is an example of some of the problems this port has.  If you can't be bothered to read that review, here is a pros and cons list:  Pros: - Multiple campaign endings - Good multiplayer customisation - Good options menu - No aim assist for controllers - Good Zombies maps in the Season Pass (Origins, Mob of the Dead, Buried) - 90 FOV - Alright PC optimisation  Cons: - Screen tear (most people are not affected) - Green Run is awful - People calling you a hacker 24/7 - Lack of Season Pass holders in multiplayer - Lack of players altogether (around 5,000 in mutliplayer on PC compared to 60,000 on 360)  Only buy this game on sale or on sites like g/ 2/ a . com (sorry I had to space out the website address, as the website is a censored word). Only buy the Season Pass if it is on sale and you mainly want to play Zombies.

This game is hated by many and loved by few, I am one of the few who actually enjoy and have enjoyed this game. For this reduced price (30€) I can certainly recommend the game. The multiplayer is solid, like pretty much every Call of Duty. There are a few innovations over Black Ops and Modern Warfare 3, like the revamped killstreaks, the class creation system, weapon unlocking mechaning, and some pretty unique weapons. The maps are alright, nothing to special there. I can recommend Nuketown 2025 and Hijacked the most since I always seemed to have the most fun on them. I don't really like the perks since some of them like 'Dexterity' or 'Toughness' are just pretty much no-brainers and you always end up taking them no matter what, really hurting variety in the respect. Same goes for the weapon pool in some respect, I'd have liked to see more than 4 weapons in the majority of categories. The only categories that DO have more than 4 weapons available are Assault Rifles and SMGs, everything else doesn't offer much variety. As for weapon balance, its pretty good fram what I experienced. There a some, if very few over/underpowerd guns like the 'Executioner' which is a terrible shotgun-revolver-thingy, and some that are mostly stronger than everything else in its class like the 'AN-94'. That's another problem right there: Since the classes mostly only have 4 weapons available, its pretty common that one gun kind of trumps that class. For example, there are 4 LMGs. Two of them are Beltfed and the other two are magazine based, which leaves te first two with larger magazines and longer reload times, while the other two are the exact opposite. One of those LMGs in each category is more long-range and the other more short-range capable. Now, one of the first attribute is going to end up being better than the other one. There is just no balancing right there, it's more or less a fact. Same goes for the second attribute, which leads to one gun of the four of them being the best allrounder, even if it lacks a few skills the other guns have. And that again leads to you, and most people online just using that one gun in every class. I would like to tell you can use these guns situtaionally, for example if you play a long-ranged map like Metldown you can use the long-range HAMR, or if you play a short-ranged one like Nuketown you just use the QBB LSW. But you can't really do that unless you're willing to actually go out of your way and pay anoter 1,99€ for a slotpack DLC, because you only get 5 custom classes by default! That doesn't leave you with much flexibility when it comes to choosing situatinal weapons, because if you're anything like me you'll want to have at least one custom class for every weapon category, and not four classes just for LMGs. Also, if you're going into this thinking of quickscoping, I have to tell you that you're probably better of with anoter CoD that suits itself better to that. Don't get me wrong, its perfectly possible but due to long zoom-in times with pretty much every sight and extremely slow firerates AND bolt-action prolonging time inbetween shots, it's pretty damn challenging since you can get mowed down so very fast. If you do want to try it out though anyways, I can safely tell you that the 'Ballista' with an ACOG-Scope is by far the best candidate for quickscoping.  I think that's all I wanted to say. For 30€ (Or your reginal equivalent) I can definetely recommend this game for all the fun I had, which do almost completely shadow the flaws I just mentioned for awareness purposes. Singleplayer:    Approximately 6 hours long, it's what you'd expect from a CoD Campaign. It's pretty much a non-stop interactive action movie with a good variety of guns (of which you can choose in your loadout before a mission) and, you guessed it, quick time events. The story is decent but I felt that the Strikeforce missions were subpar. I would describe them as RTS x FPS x Wave-based shooter missions that had objectives to complete, but I just felt like they were a fill-in for the (in my opinion) short single-player campaign. I enjoyed the futuristic setting, but I just felt like the overall presentation was slightly lacking. Having said all of this, I have to say that I did enjoy the singleplayer but, if that's what you're wanting to pay $90 for, then I'd suggest you give it a miss.    Multiplayer:    Unless you've been living under a rock for the past number of years, you're most likely interested in CoD because of the multiplayer (or Zombies...). I put a tad over 40 hours into it (because I joined the party late... 2 years late, that is) and, I have to say, it was enjoyable. Frustrating at times with connection issues but, for the most part, it was fun. 2 CoDs have been released since this one, though, so you may find that the playerbase is lacking. I live in Australia, and I had no troubles finding people to play with on 50ms ping, which is good considering the age of this game now (in terms of CoD's lifespan...). A good variety of weapons and maps and, again, the futuristic settings was a nice change to the semi-bland modern settings we've seen in the past. It isn't worth the $90 asking price it is now, so I'd say get it on sale (or somewhere cheaper...).    Zombies:    I have to say, I was a fan of the zombies mode that appeared in the original Black Ops, but unfortunately (mainly due to a lack in playerbase) the zombies mode in this game did nothing for me. I'm sure it would be a lot of fun with friends, but unfortunately because I got this 2 years after release, I had to go solo, which I found kinda lame... I did only play this for about an hour, so be sure to check out other reviews instead of relying on me!    Verdict:    - Fun game, especially with the variety of Singleplayer, Multiplayer and Zombies - The futuristic setting is a welcome change to the CoD formula - Unfortunately due to it's age (now), it's lacking in a Zombies playerbase, but it currently maintains a decent Multiplayer population  This over-the-top action first-person shooter is worth playing but I can't recommend it for it's price, so get it when it's on sale (if you're interested)! The Call of Duty hate game is strong. Every year, thousands of gamers rush to the forums to vent their hatred for the infamous series. While many of the complaitns are fair complaints, they aren't complaints with the game more so with the popularity of the game.   Pros: the game controls almost perfectly. One of the upsides of making the same game over and over is you learn how to do it well. Your character responds precisely and quickly. Also, the zombies mode is awesome. I hate calling it perfect, but really it's extremely good. I found myself buying the game AGAIN on the xBox 360 JUST so I could do split screen zombies with my friends. Standard mode is good, and grief is entertaining, but really tranzit is the real gem here. Basically you travel map to map in a bus and can get different guns and do different things at each map. However if the bus leaves and you aren't on it, you can get stuck at one map for 4-5 turns with nothing but the wall weapons (usually). It's tense when the bus leaves and you're stuck surviving round 15 with almost no amunition for your good gun, knowing that if you don't get full ammo you'll be stuck with a pea shooter.   Cons: well, here's what most of you wanted to read. Firstly the multiplayer shows little to no energy. I'm not talking about reused ideas, more that what's there is done slopply at best. The maps are bland and ofter have spots that can be exploited to wreck havok. While it's fun when you're the one doing it, nothing sucks more than to die to an unkillable sniper. The single player isn't so much a con as it just is not great. It is short and for the most part forgetable. It's really just a feature rather than the main point of the game. Something to show in the trailers. Sure it has cool moments, but the futuristic tech is almost always (unfortunatly) just used in quicktime events and what you're left with is your average Call of Duty.   In short, if you're a fan of the series, go ahead and buy it. It's a faithful entery in the series with enough new features to keep you entertained. If you're not a fan, don't get it, there's nothing really new to change your mind. To be honest, it doesn't matter what I say because 99% already have made up your minds. Readers looking for an in-depth review of Black Ops II’s multiplayer, I’m sorry to disappoint. My knowledge in that area is minimal and as far as I’m concerned, nothing’s changed since the last iteration (save for some new weapons and maps). It’s still a fun and solid experience rivaled only by few others, but my true qualifications as a reviewer lie mainly in single player.  Despite Black Ops II’s static multiplayer component, the game still shows effort to break new ground through its ambitious campaign. As usual, the plot involves some conspiracy to incite global warfare, but this time, it’s one worth revisiting even after the credits have rolled. Since the first Black Ops, Treyarch (one of three Call of Duty developers alongside Infinity Ward and Sledgehammer Games) has shown a knack for storytelling. Their talents are still clearly visible here through their complex narrative cleverly woven together by events of the Cold War and Treyarch’s vision of the year 2025.  For the first time in Call of Duty history, the campaign offers branching storylines that are shaped by missions with multiple endings (determined by whether or not objectives were achieved) and choices made by the player. In the case of the later, decisions don’t boil down to choosing from a list, but are made with gameplay mechanics, be it interacting with the environment or choosing which limb to shoot. Often times, you’ll play through these moments without even realizing that alternate options existed and that’s what makes Black Ops II great - it encourages players to reconsider their actions. Ultimately, the secrets found and choices made will determine which of the five ways the game can end.  Also new is a tower defense-like mini game in which the player must direct troops against waves of enemies in bird’s-eye view. At any moment, the player may assume first person control of a friendly unit on the battlefield and play as normal. These missions, known as Strike Force missions, serve as supplements to the main story, unlocking themselves when certain conditions are met. They’re a welcomed addition and help immensely to vary the gameplay.  As proud as I am of Treyarch, especially for their contributions to the single player, there’s still plenty of room for improvement. In vehicle segments, handling feels extremely sluggish and the unrealistic physics breaks all immersion. The script is filled with clichés and the absurdity of some missions should have been toned down. Stages set in 2025 introduce several game-changing gadgets with promising potential that never reappear. But the biggest culprit of all is the fact that Black Ops II feels like a glorified game of Whack-a-Mole where enemies repeatedly pop out for you to shoot.  Multiplayer and single player aside, there’s still the topic of Zombie Mode. The new features here are a separate campaign and a new 8 player game type. While Treyarch’s efforts are appreciated, the final product is all but satisfying. The “campaign” merely consists of ordinary survival maps strung together by cutscenes and fighting zombies with an army makes an already dull experience even duller.  It’s refreshing to see a developer cater to the single player fans for a title with a track record for being predominantly multiplayer. In doing so, Treyarch has raised the bar for first person shooter narratives. Regardless of what comes from Infinity Ward next year, I can honestly say that I eagerly await Treyarch’s next release, knowing very well that they aren’t one to shy away from being different.  Grade: 4/5

After playing this game for so long and enjoying it, I really thought about what I was playing. And I don't reccomend it. This review goes for most COD games before MW3.  First of all, the community. Gutter trash. Need I say more? Let me go in detail. You play well, you are a tryhard/have no life You play badly, you are a noob You stay in cover tactically to avoid getting killed, and you are a camper and a 'fegit' You use a sniper rifle properly you are a 'hardscoping noob' Basically, you can't do anything without people complaining. If you are trying to find friends to play with, dont start from the game itself, get into a group or something. Hell, you have to be Indiana Jones to find a good person to play with in-game. Make one little slip-up and your whole team can be hurting your fillings.   The gameplay. Yeah, the graphics look nice. I'm impressed with the optimization for low-end computers. My bad lenovo laptop can run this game 60fps on medium textures, which is really good. It can be action packed at some points. But usually it's just repetetive. Shoot a guy. Run. Shoot the other guy. Run. And so on. Nobody even goes for the objectives in the objective gamemodes. If you're in combat training, (that's the only way you can really get into objective games since nobody really plays the standalone objective modes) don't think people are gonna be capturing any flags in CTF. At points playing, you might just think to yourself ; Is this fun?  Graphics: The graphics are probably this game's strong suit. Greatly optimized.  Controls: Easy to get used to.   Singleplayer: Fun. Lots of choices for different endings. If you are getting an FPS for singleplayer, get BO2. For multiplayer, I would reccomend a title like battlefield.  With the regular modes, you can be put with people with totally different skill ranges than you. I believe league play puts you with people in your skill level, but I don't think anyone uses that anymore.  TL;DR, this game is greatly graphically optimized, can be fun for some time, but can be repetetive after some time. The community is gutter trash, but you can't expect much from competetive players trying to get under your skin to gain some edge.

I'm going to base this review mostly on Zombies because that is what I have played the most and enjoy the most about this Call of Duty. There are spoilers in this review. The campaign is really good. It has intense moments, its emotional moments and its action crazy moments. It’s fun because the action changes and does not repeat over and over. The story sometimes talks about what happened in the past which was not explained in Black Ops 1, some games chapters revert to the past so you are playing in the past. This helps fill the gaps in Black Ops 1 and helps explain some new things in the current campaign. Multiplayer is also really fun. The guns seem to have a nice level of damage so the guns do seem fair. A lot of the maps are great and momentum changes based upon the map you are playing so again it does not repeat. NOTE: there are a few lobbies online that are modded. ZOMBIES!!! Even though I don’t particularly like one or two maps, they are all amazing. Each map has its own atmosphere that suits the map and its lighting. There are some great weapons and some new awesome perks to help you fend off the undead. Some of the buildables in the game are fun to use and helpful in surviving. Each map just as it did in Black Ops 1 features its own unique Easter Egg which continues the story from World at War. It’s fun figuring out the steps towards completion and finding out what happens next. But in doing so makes more questions and anticipation for the next map. In my opinion, Zombies is the best Call of Duty mode created so far and its intricate story like makes it that much better.

The last good call of duty IMO and arguably the best. I have played this game since day 1 on 360 and recently moved to PC where I find its even better.   Whatever though you can find 100s of reviews about how good the game is that are better than anything I could write and if you own this already you already know how good it is. what I'm going to talk about is a question I see a lot: should I still get this and do people still play?  First off should you buy this game: Hell yes BUT I'd either wait for a steam sale or find a cheap physical copy as it's full price is expensive for a 4 year old game. Also you will want to buy the seasons pass (all of the DLC maps in one package) or you will have trouble finding matches and will sometimes be put in DLC lobbies anyways only to be booted when people vote for a DLC map. If you haven't played a call of duty before I would still get this even though there are many amazing players it's a game that is fun even when you're bad and it's a fun experience to learn by fighting g players that can sometimes be 10x better than you. How else do you improve lol.  Now the other question: do people still play? Yes there can be from the minimum I've seen at low hours 1500 to 6000 on holidays and long weekends during peak hours. Don't be fooled by the low playercount that appears in the black ops 2 community hub, this game has 3 executables for multiplayer campaign and zombies and so 3 community hubs for each but the store page automatically takes you to the campaigns community Hub. Most of the time you can easily find games in: TDM, domination, demolition, search and destroy, hardpoint as well as a lobby called 'nukejacked' which is a rotation of all game modes on the maps NUKEtown and hiJACKED (hence the name) with more players than usual lobbies it's good for playing modes that aren't populated such as gun game, and for levelling up most weapons however if you get angry easily, are new to the game or want a more chill experience I'd avoid nukejacked. During off peak hours some gamemodes will be impossible to find however you can always find a match of TDM and nukejacked. Hardcore TDM and search and destroy have a good amount of players too if your into that.  I hope I've helped to answer some questions and to help people make an informed decision about whether they should buy this game or not. This game still holds up well today and is still 100x better than any COD game released after. There are many challenges to complete as well (like getting diamond camo) which give the game more to do than just running around shooting.  If you have other legitimate questions about this game drop a comment and I will be happy to answer to the best of my knowledge.  11/10 would never use jetpacks again...

I'm only talking about the singleplayer campaign as that's what I'm looking for in CoD games.   It's ambitious - a big story with different endings according to how you play and what you do. But it's not really working. You know, this is one of those stories where the bad guy is *always* one giant step ahead, even able to turn around the tables when he's in chains under high security aboard an US fleet carrier. That's something you've come to expect in Batman movies, but here it is just too much. This at least partly explains why I liked the much more conventional story of 'CoD Ghosts' better - it also requires a fair amount of suspension of disbelief, but not THAT much.   Then I confess didn' quite like the 'strategy' missions (strike force missions). They tried something new here, I give them that, but it doesn't work too well in a shooter. At least not for me. Luckily, we only have to complete one of those, but then again we can't get the best ending if we don't successfully complete all of them.   Game hanged itself up a couple of times too, nothing too bad, but it shouldn't be.   It's a good game and I enjoyed it (and will come back), but sometimes less is more.
